children.title: challenges
children.comment: God makes demands on his people and, often through spiritual leaders, confronts believers with their sin. He also calls to account false gods and those who exalt themselves against him. The wicked vainly challenge God by questioning his authority, seeking to resist his power and opposing his people.

cschildren.title: God's challenge to his people

children.title: The challenge to serve him alone

cschildren.title: Challenging one another's sin

children.title: The call to rebuke and admonish
Examples of leaders who challenged the sins of others

secondaryrefs.comment: Ezekiel was called to confront Jerusalem
Hosea challenges the unfaithfulness of Israel

cschildren.title: God's sovereignty is unchallengeable
God's challenge to the wicked
Challenges to God and his people

seealsos.comment: Isaiah's opponents challenge God to do what he has announced.
Jesus Christ is tempted by the devil
Jesus Christ is challenged by Peter
God's people are equipped to stand against the devil's attacks

cschildren.title: Further examples of challenges

children.title: claims
children.comment: The assertion of rights and recognition due. God as Creator and Redeemer makes claims on his world and on his people. The claims of Jesus Christ about himself as God and Messiah call for a response. In human relationships, too, claims are made by individuals about themselves and, as a result, on others.

cschildren.title: The basis for God's claims

children.title: God owns his people as Creator
God owns his people as Redeemer

cschildren.title: The priority of God's claims
Acknowledging God's claims on human life
The claims of Jesus Christ

children.title: Jesus Christ's claim to fulfil the OT
Jesus' claim to be the Messiah
Jesus Christ's claim to be king of the Jews

seealsos.comment: Forgiveness of sin was recognised as the prerogative of God alone. Jesus Christ's claim to forgive sin is thus a claim to be God

children.title: Jesus Christ's claim to universal lordship
The ``I am'' claims of Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: the way and the truth and the life

children.title: The need to acknowledge Jesus Christ's claims

cschildren.title: Human claims

secondaryrefs.comment: the proud boasting of the wicked
false prophets claim to speak God's word
Simon the sorcerer claimed to be someone great

children.title: Claims must be verified by actions

secondaryrefs.comment: Israel's claim on David as their king
Nehemiah's enemies have no claim on Jerusalem.
false accusations made against the righteous
Believers will be slandered by their enemies
The Jews claim that Jesus Christ's powers are demonic

children.title: commands
children.comment: Demands made of his people, or obligations laid upon his people, by God. Scripture stresses that being the people of God involves responsibilities as well as privileges, and sets out the demands which God justly makes of his people.

children.title: commands, in OT
children.comment: The OT sets out the commands of God to his people Israel, indicating both their extent and their importance.

children.title: The reason for God's commands: the need to be holy

seealsos.comment: The LORD commands generosity and kindness to the poor

children.title: Demands made by God upon individuals
The sword, symbolising the judgment of God
Commands of the leaders of God's people
God's commands are to be loved
God's commands are to be obeyed
Warnings against and examples of disobedience
commands, in NT
children.comment: The NT sets out the commands of God and Jesus Christ for the church.

children.title: In the rest of the NT

seealsos.comment: ``the command'' (see 2Pe 2:21) here refers to Christianity considered as a body of ethical teaching

primaryrefs.comment: They received the command to love at the beginning of their Christian experience.

seealsos.comment: The Greek word translated ``decisions'' literally means ``decrees''
``these commandments'' probably refers to the OT law as fulfilled by Jesus Christ (see Mt 5:17-18)

children.title: Obedience is an expression of love and faithfulness

Claudius ordered all the Jews to leave Rome

confession, of Jesus Christ
children.comment: A public declaration of faith in Jesus Christ, acknowledging both his divinity and his lordship. Without such, salvation is impossible.

cschildren.title: Confession of faith in Jesus Christ is necessary for salvation
Confessing Jesus Christ as Lord is only possible by the Holy Spirit
Results of confessing faith in Jesus Christ
Demons confessed Jesus Christ's divinity
Ultimately all will confess Jesus Christ's lordship
Notable confessions of faith in Jesus Christ
The refusal to confess Jesus Christ

children.title: decision-making
children.comment: The ability to arrive at a decision after due consideration of all the factors involved. The Christian life involves making decisions at many levels. Scripture offers guidance concerning how such decisions should be made, and provides examples of good and bad decision-making.

children.title: decision-making, and providence
children.comment: People need guidance from God about how they should make up their minds on difficult issues. God gives them this through the Holy Spirit, the Scriptures, individuals, groups and other external means.

children.title: Decisions should be grounded in a relationship with God

seealsos.comment: Wisdom involves making right moral decisions

children.title: The work of the Holy Spirit in decision-making
Humility is essential for divine guidance
decision-making, examples of
children.comment: Scripture provides examples of good and bad decision-making, as well as offering guidance as to how decisions ought to be made.

seealsos.comment: Saul made the offering in Samuel's absence
Judas decided to betray Jesus Christ for money
the decision to put Jesus Christ to death

children.title: The sovereignty of God in decision-making

seealsos.comment: Balaam could only curse or bless at the LORD's bidding

children.title: Good decision-making involves consideration for others
All decision-making must be subject to the will of God
decision-making, and providence
children.comment: People need guidance from God about how they should make up their minds on difficult issues. God gives them this through the Holy Spirit, the Scriptures, individuals, groups and other external means.

children.title: Decisions should be grounded in a relationship with God

seealsos.comment: Balaam could only curse or bless at the LORD's bidding

decisions
children.comment: The end result of a process of reflection upon possible courses of action, informed and sustained by a concern to please God.

cschildren.title: Factors that should affect believers' decision-making

seealsos.comment: Ignoring God's will leads to destruction

children.title: Confidence in God's readiness to reveal his will
Belief in God's overall plan for his people
God's promise to guide believers in their decisions
edification
children.comment: The building up and strengthening in the faith of believers and churches. Believers are strengthened by God and are urged, too, to build up one another. The church is edified through God's word, through the Holy Spirit and the proper use of spiritual gifts, through the church's appointed ministries and through the mutual love, support and encouragement of its members.

cschildren.title: God edifies his people by strengthening them
The edification of believers

children.title: God builds up the community of faith
Believers are to build themselves up
Believers are to build one another up

cschildren.title: The means of edification

seealsos.comment: Abraham was strengthened in his faith by his acceptance of God's promise

secondaryrefs.comment: The message from the Jerusalem apostles results in believers being strengthened.

cschildren.title: Examples of those who edified others
The goal of edification

children.title: encouragement
children.comment: Giving someone confidence and courage to do something. Scripture encourages believers to trust in God and to rely on the enabling of the Holy Spirit.

children.title: encouragement, examples of
children.comment: Believers can encourage one another to have greater confidence in God and so to be bolder in living out their faith.

primaryrefs.comment: King Hezekiah encourages his people.

seealsos.comment: Paul to the church at Rome

children.title: Encouragement as exhortation in the life of faith

primaryrefs.comment: Paul describes his ministry.
Condemnation of Israel's leaders.

children.title: Scripture censures those who encourage others to do evil

seealsos.comment: after David and Joab had arranged Uriah's death

children.title: encouragement, promises of God's
children.comment: God promises continual support for his people, particularly when they become weary, depressed or disillusioned.

children.title: Means by which God encourages believers
Meditation on his law and word

primaryrefs.comment: The word used for Spirit here means ``Counsellor'' or ``one who encourages or comforts''.

children.title: God's encouragement experienced through the words and actions of others

secondaryrefs.comment: Gideon and the dream of the Midianite soldier
the returned exiles helped by the king of Assyria

children.title: endurance
children.comment: The ability to persevere in a task or calling. The Christian is called to endure in the face of trial or opposition, and his endurance brings spiritual rewards.

cschildren.title: Endurance commended as a virtue for God's people
Endurance is a hallmark of true Christian profession
Christian endurance originates with God
Christian endurance involves standing firm
The results of enduring
Examples of endurance

children.title: enlightenment
children.comment: The illumination of the mind, especially by the word of God, leading to delight and increased pleasure in God.

cschildren.title: Enlightenment as God-given understanding and insight
Enlightenment through the word of God
God needs no enlightenment

children.title: equipping
children.comment: The providing of all necessary facilities for achieving a task. Scripture suggests that God does not provide tasks for believers without also providing the gifts which are needed to equip believers for those tasks.

children.title: equipping, physical
children.comment: Scripture provides illustrations of situations in which people are equipped to carry out physical actions.

children.title: Manual workers are equipped for their tasks
Travellers are equipped for their journeys
Those equipped with signs of authority
equipping, spiritual
children.comment: Scripture provides examples of individuals who have been equipped to carry out tasks or responsibilities of a spiritual nature.

children.title: Jesus Christ was equipped for his work
God's people are equipped for service
Believers are equipped for spiritual tasks
By the call of Jesus Christ
By the empowering of the Holy Spirit
equipping, physical
children.comment: Scripture provides illustrations of situations in which people are equipped to carry out physical actions.

children.title: Manual workers are equipped for their tasks
Travellers are equipped for their journeys
Those equipped with signs of authority
equipping, spiritual
children.comment: Scripture provides examples of individuals who have been equipped to carry out tasks or responsibilities of a spiritual nature.

children.title: Jesus Christ was equipped for his work
God's people are equipped for service
Believers are equipped for spiritual tasks
By the call of Jesus Christ
By the empowering of the Holy Spirit
evangelism
children.comment: The proclamation of the good news of Jesus Christ, which arises naturally from believers' love for God and appreciation of all that God has done for them. The NT stresses the importance of evangelism, and provides guidance as to how it should be carried out.

children.title: evangelism, nature of
children.comment: Evangelism focuses on the proclaiming of the good news of the coming of the kingdom of God in Christ, including the forgiveness of sins and the hope of eternal life, through the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Evangelism as the proclamation of good news
Jesus Christ as the focus of evangelism
The gospel message is revealed by God
The gospel message centres on Jesus Christ
God's promises are fulfilled in Jesus Christ
The call to repentance for the forgiveness of sins
The announcement of peace with God

primaryrefs.comment: Miracles are part of the gospel proclamation, demonstrating that the kingdom of God has come

children.title: evangelism, motivation for
children.comment: Evangelism arises from a natural response to the grace of God, a concern for those who have yet to hear the good news and a desire to be faithful to the great commission to bring the good news to the ends of the earth. Evangelism is guided and directed by the Holy Spirit.

children.title: A desire to win the lost
God opens the door for evangelism
Areas of ministry assigned by God
Evangelism as a result of persecution
evangelism, kinds of
children.comment: Scripture recognises that evangelism takes place in a variety of contexts, and offers models for evangelism in today's church.

primaryrefs.comment: Paul begins his evangelism in Gentile cities by building links within the Jewish community.

children.title: Making a public defence to accusers

primaryrefs.comment: Peter visits Cornelius' home to speak to those assembled.
Though the gospel is for all people without distinction, evangelism among certain people and groups enabled the message to spead further.

seealsos.comment: Paul before Sergius Paulus, proconsul of Cyprus
Paul before Felix and his wife
Paul in the home of the chief official on Malta

primaryrefs.comment: The conversion of the head of the household was often accompanied by the conversion of the whole family group.

children.title: example
children.comment: A person who acts as an illustration or model. Scripture provides examples of both good and bad conduct for the guidance of believers.

cschildren.title: Scripture provides examples to inform and warn believers

children.title: Israel is an example to believers
Job as an example of perseverance and patience
The example of Jesus Christ is of special importance to Christians
The apostles set an example for believers to follow
Christian leaders are to provide examples to their people

cschildren.title: Biblical examples to be imitated
Biblical examples to be avoided

children.title: fasting
children.comment: Abstaining from food, and possibly drink, for a limited period of time as a mark of religious commitment and devotion or as an expression of repentance for sins.

children.title: fasting, nature of
children.comment: Scripture frequently refers to individuals fasting and describes the different kinds of fast which may be undertaken.

children.title: One day: the normal fast period
Forty days
children.precomment: These 40-day fasts are all in unique circumstances and are not prescribed:

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote at verse 29.

children.title: fasting, reasons for
children.comment: Scripture identifies a number of situations in which fasting is appropriate.

children.title: Situations in which fasting is appropriate

seealsos.comment: Daniel identifies himself with the sin of the people
Moses fasts before the revelation of the Law
The church receives direction through the Holy Spirit while fasting.

children.title: fasting, practice of
children.comment: Although fasting is a negative practice, it is not an end in itself but is to be undertaken for a positive purpose.

children.title: Fasting is not an end in itself
Fasting as empty ritual is condemned
Fasting as mere show is condemned

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ repudiated fasting for its own sake whilst granting that there is a time and a place for it.
The motivation here is similar to that in abstaining from food.

children.title: fasting, nature of
children.comment: Scripture frequently refers to individuals fasting and describes the different kinds of fast which may be undertaken.

Forty days
children.precomment: These 40-day fasts are all in unique circumstances and are not prescribed:

children.comment: Scripture identifies a number of situations in which fasting is appropriate.

seealsos.comment: Daniel identifies himself with the sin of the people
Moses fasts before the revelation of the Law
The church receives direction through the Holy Spirit while fasting.

children.comment: Although fasting is a negative practice, it is not an end in itself but is to be undertaken for a positive purpose.

children.title: Fasting is not an end in itself
Fasting as empty ritual is condemned
Fasting as mere show is condemned

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ repudiated fasting for its own sake whilst granting that there is a time and a place for it.
The motivation here is similar to that in abstaining from food.

children.title: giving
children.comment: Dedicating or offering something or oneself to others or to God. Scripture stresses the importance of giving. The generosity and love of God in giving his only Son to die for his people is understood to lead to an obligation, on their part, to love God and others in return.

children.title: giving, of oneself
children.comment: The submission of the self to the will of God, in thanksgiving and service.

children.title: Jesus Christ's self-giving as an example to believers
Why self-giving is reasonable service to God
God's people belong to him by creation
God's people belong to him by redemption
All good things are given by God
giving, of possessions
children.comment: Making one's possession available for God's service in the way in which he directs, as a practical recognition that all possessions come from him.

children.title: Ministries that require the giving of material possessions
The care of widows and orphans
Motives for the giving of material possessions
The manner of giving material possessions
With a reckoning different from the world's
With regard for people's capacity to give

seealsos.comment: encouragement to be enterprising in giving

children.title: God's giving: the model for his people's giving
giving, of talents
children.comment: All human abilities and skills derive from God and are to be dedicated to his glory and the good of others.

children.title: Talents are given and sustained by God
Talents are to be devoted to God
Talents are to be accounted for
Rewards according to use or misuse of talents
giving, of time
children.comment: People are stewards of a deposit of time given by God, and will be held responsible for the way in which they use it.

children.title: God will demand an account of how time has been spent
By making the most of present opportunities
Time is to be spent wisely
Time is to be allocated according to priorities

glorifying God
children.comment: The giving of glory to God through acts of praise and obedience. Believers are to glorify God in their lives, as Jesus Christ glorified him in his life.

cschildren.title: Believers are to glorify God

children.title: God is entitled to be glorified
Glorifying God is the believer's natural response to him

cschildren.title: God is glorified in Jesus Christ
Reasons for glorifying God
Means of glorifying God

children.title: By doing good works and bearing fruit

cschildren.title: Examples of glorifying God

secondaryrefs.comment: Mary, the mother of Jesus Christ

children.title: goals
children.comment: Jesus Christ's basic aim was to do his Father's will. Believers have the same objective, which Jesus Christ and the Holy Spirit enable them to achieve.

cschildren.title: God's goals

children.title: To build his church in Christ
To perfect his church in Christ

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ's goals
Believers' goals

children.title: To be faithful to Jesus Christ
God guarantees that believers will reach their goal
good works
children.comment: Acts designed specifically to benefit others, which are characteristic of God. He requires and enables his people to do good, although such is contrary to their sinful human nature. Salvation does not depend on good works, but leads to them.

cschildren.title: Good works are characteristic of God
Good works are unnatural for sinful human beings
God's people are encouraged to do good works
God is pleased with the good works of his people
Good works will be rewarded
Good works as evidence of repentance
Good works as evidence of God's grace in the lives of believers
Good works are the purpose of the new creation
Jesus Christ criticised for doing good works on the Sabbath

children.title: growth
children.comment: The process of development and maturing, used to refer to the progress of the kingdom of God and the spiritual development of believers. Scripture uses images of growth (such as seeds, plants and infants) to stress the dynamic nature of personal faith and the kingdom of God.

cschildren.title: Images of growth
The apostles worked and prayed for growth in believers
Dimensions of spiritual growth
Growth comes from God
Growth comes through discipleship

children.title: Contributing to growth in the church by exercising gifts

cschildren.title: Examples of spiritual growth in some of God's servants
The growth of the kingdom of God

children.title: God promises that his kingdom will grow
The early church experienced rapid numerical growth
honouring God
children.comment: Giving the reverence and respect to God which is his due. All God's people have a duty to honour him in every aspect of their lives, while unbelievers and even animals can also honour him.

cschildren.title: God's people must honour him
Ways of honouring God

children.title: By keeping the Sabbath and religious feasts
By honouring his name and his word
By giving tithes and offerings to him

cschildren.title: God honours those who honour him
God requires sincerity from those who honour him
All people will ultimately honour God
Jesus Christ is to be honoured as God

children.title: hospitality
children.comment: Acts of generosity and friendship towards strangers. God's people are called to be hospitable as part of their duty to others and in gratitude for the salvation they have received from God. Showing hospitality includes the responsibility to protect those received as guests.

children.title: hospitality, a duty of God's people
Hospitality is a responsibility of leaders
Hospitality is to be offered to Christian ministers
Hospitality is to be refused to false teachers
Hospitality as a picture of salvation

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ comes as a willing guest to the repentant, as a sign of renewed fellowship.

children.title: hospitality, examples of
children.comment: Scripture provides many examples of friendship and generosity towards strangers, and encourages believers to be hospitable in turn.

children.title: Examples of hospitality in the OT

Manoah receives the angel of the LORD.

The widow of Zarephath cares for Elijah despite her poverty
Nehemiah shows hospitality to fellow Jews.

imitating
children.comment: Following the example or copying the actions of another person. Christians are called upon to become Christlike. Becoming like Jesus Christ is, however, the result, not the condition, of conversion.

cschildren.title: The people of God are to imitate God
The people of God are to imitate Jesus Christ

children.title: Jesus Christ is the example for believers
God works in believers making them like Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Good examples to imitate

children.title: Christians are to imitate the good example of other believers
Christian leaders are to set examples which can be imitated
Believers are to imitate the good example of those who have gone before

cschildren.title: God's people are not to imitate bad examples

children.title: Israel must not imitate other nations
God's people must not imitate the ungodly

cschildren.title: No-one can obtain salvation by imitating Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ teaches that salvation (eternal life) is a consequence of faith in him. He never links salvation with imitating him or any other act or acts.

children.title: martyrdom
children.comment: The term ``martyr'' comes from the Greek word for ``witness'', reminding believers that the supreme act of witness for the gospel is to give up one's life for its sake.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as martyr

children.title: Jesus Christ had to suffer and die

primaryrefs.comment: In that Jesus Christ gives up his life, he may be thought of as a martyr. But the NT stresses that he is far more than this. Through his death alone come all the benefits of salvation, in which all believers can share.

children.title: Jesus Christ's life is given as a ransom for believers

cschildren.title: Other examples of martyrdom

secondaryrefs.comment: Stephen is the first martyr of the Christian church.

cschildren.title: Noble qualities of martyrs
Martyrdom must be recognised as a possibility for all believers
Reasons for martyrdom

children.title: Refusal to engage in false worship

cschildren.title: Methods of martyrdom

Rewards of martyrdom

children.title: mortification
children.comment: The act of self-denial or the ``putting to death'' of sinful instincts in order to have freedom from sin and to live in the power of the Holy Spirit. The NT stresses that this act of humiliation comes about through the grace of God. It is the result of, not the condition for, conversion.

cschildren.title: Examples of mortification through humility
Examples of mortification through self-denial
Mortification as the basis for discipleship

children.title: The necessity of putting to death sinful human nature and the world's values

cschildren.title: Dying to self is a means of knowing freedom from sin
The importance of sharing in the death of Christ
The example of Paul
Mortification is not the same as self-infliction

children.title: neighbours, duty to
children.comment: Scripture defines the identity of neighbours in various ways, and indicates the nature and extent of believers' obligations to them.

cschildren.title: Neighbours defined

children.title: Those who show mercy to people in need

cschildren.title: Duties to neighbours
Prohibition of negative actions towards neighbours

children.title: obedience
children.comment: A willingness to submit to the authority of someone else and to actually do what one is asked or told to do. Scripture lays particular emphasis upon the need for believers to obey God, stressing his trustworthiness. This obedience is especially clear in the life and death of Jesus Christ.

children.title: obedience, to God
children.comment: A willingness to submit oneself to the will of God and to put it into effect. Scripture emphasises the necessity for God's laws to be followed, gives examples and reasons, and describes the rewards.

children.title: Obedience is demanded of God's people
Examples of obedience in the OT
By the wind and the waves

primaryrefs.comment: Obedience to the will of God demonstrates the reality of a person's faith in Jesus Christ.

children.title: God rewards those who obey him
Obedience to the word of God
Examples of people who obeyed God
obedience, to human authorities
children.comment: Scripture teaches that all people, Christians included, should submit not only to God himself but also to divinely instituted secular authorities.

children.title: Obedience is owed to church leaders
Obedience is owed within the household
Obedience to secular authority is limited by obedience to God
obedience, to God
children.comment: A willingness to submit oneself to the will of God and to put it into effect. Scripture emphasises the necessity for God's laws to be followed, gives examples and reasons, and describes the rewards.

children.title: Obedience is demanded of God's people
Examples of obedience in the OT
By the wind and the waves

primaryrefs.comment: Obedience to the will of God demonstrates the reality of a person's faith in Jesus Christ.

children.comment: Scripture teaches that all people, Christians included, should submit not only to God himself but also to divinely instituted secular authorities.

children.title: perseverance
children.comment: Enduring in a course of action or belief. In its negative sense, it can mean being stubborn; in its positive sense, it means continuing commitment to the gospel of Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Human perseverance in sin
God's perseverance in calling Israel to obedience
Jesus Christ's perseverance with those who would not believe
Christians' perseverance in faith
Perseverance arises from suffering
Perseverance builds and demonstrates Christian character
Encouragements for Christians to persevere

children.title: pleasing God
children.comment: An essential aspect of the life of believers that is more than a matter of external observance, but a total and heartfelt commitment to God.

cschildren.title: Pleasing God is commanded
It is more important to please God than to please people
Pleasing God involves inward attitudes, not simply external observance
Sacrifices and duties please God when carried out with the right attitude
Results of pleasing God
Examples of actions that please God
Examples of those concerned to pleased God by their actions
Examples of people who pleased God

children.title: priorities
children.comment: Scripture stresses that God must be allowed to rule at the heart of a person's life.

children.title: priority, of God
children.comment: Scripture provides examples of individuals who have allowed God to take priority in their lives, and also of those who have allowed something or someone else to take priority.

children.title: Disapproval of not putting God first
Examples of not putting God first
Worship commended as the highest human activity

primaryrefs.comment: David was prepared to be despised by his wife rather than inhibit his worship.

children.title: Commands to participate in the kingdom
Examples of sacrifices for the kingdom
Outstanding examples of conformity to God's will
priority, of faith, hope and love
children.comment: Putting God first--living according to his word--serves the glory of God and also the best interests of believers, by giving them true wisdom for daily living.

children.title: The wisdom of making faith a priority
Putting the fear of God before other considerations
Preferring God's way to sinful advice
Choosing imaginative action rather than laziness or fearfulness
Patient waiting rather than impetuous action
The wisdom of making hope a priority
Putting true riches above earthly wealth
Putting eternal joy before temporal hardship
The wisdom of making love a priority

primaryrefs.comment: Paul's concern that love, rather than competition over spiritual gifts, should be made a priority.

seealsos.comment: Demas' love for this world rather than loyalty

children.title: Following the Spirit rather than sinful human nature

primaryrefs.comment: Merely ``human'' activity betrays a failure of love for God.

children.title: Inner sincerity rather than outward appearance

progress
children.comment: The process of development and growth, of special importance in the life of believers. Scripture stresses the importance of progress, both of the individual believer and of the church, and the need to work towards that goal.

cschildren.title: Progress in the Christian life should be expected
Believers are to strive for progress in their Christian lives
Progress in the Christian life brings assurance
The church is expected to progress

children.title: reformation
children.comment: The process of bringing religious practices and beliefs back into line with the word of God.  The OT portrays Israel as requiring reformation at several points in her history.  God's people continue to need to review their beliefs and practices in the light of God's word.

cschildren.title: The continual need to turn from idolatry

primaryrefs.comment: Idolatry was the besetting sin of Israel and the point at which all reforms had to begin.

cschildren.title: The reform of Asa

children.title: He repaired the altar of the temple
As a result the people sought and found God

cschildren.title: The reform of Hezekiah

children.title: He removed idols and even local shrines dedicated to God
He established worship in the renovated and consecrated temple
The covenant between God and his people was renewed

cschildren.title: The reform of Josiah

secondaryrefs.comment: The prevailing attitude was that God would ensure that no disaster would befall his chosen people. Now the need to turn from sin and complacency was reiterated and repentance ensued

cschildren.title: The reforms of Ezra and Nehemiah

children.title: The problem of intermarriage was dealt with

primaryrefs.comment: The objection to intermarriage was based on religious not racial grounds.  It led to a corruption of the faith.

cschildren.title: Incomplete reforms
The call to reform

children.title: reminders
children.comment: The means of calling to mind important matters or events. Scripture stresses the importance of being reminded of God's dealings with his people in the past.

cschildren.title: The importance of being reminded of God's words and deeds
Reminders of God's covenant and faithfulness
Reminders of God's intervention in history
Reminders to people of their sin or shortcomings
Reminders to people to be faithful to God
Reminders to people of their potential and gifts from God
Reminders to God's people on matters of faith and conduct

children.title: renunciation
children.comment: The deliberate rejection or disavowal, especially of a person or object.

cschildren.title: Renunciation of the LORD
Renunciation of evil
Self-renunciation and the Christian life

children.title: respect
children.comment: An attitude of reverence and deference, reflecting an appreciation of the significance of the person or thing that is esteemed.

children.title: respect, for God's character
children.comment: God's revelation of himself calls for deference, honour and a response of right living.

children.title: Respect for God's ark and sanctuary
Respect for God leads to godly living
respect, for human beings
children.comment: Each individual, created in the image of God, should be honoured and esteemed, and this should be worked out in every area of life.

children.title: Human beings are to be respected
They are made in the image of God
The bounds of life belong to God
The equality and dignity of human beings is commanded
Examples of those who respected their parents
Respect at the place of work
respect, for environment
children.comment: Although God created the universe and retains ultimate ownership of it, he has delegated responsibility for the well-being of the earth to the human race. This stewardship includes the care of the animal kingdom and the earth's natural resources.

children.title: God's creation is to be respected
Responsibility to rule and care for the earth has been delegated to the human race
God himself maintains a caring supervision of his creation
Respect for all nature and animals

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote.

children.title: Respect and care for the earth's natural resources

children.comment: God's revelation of himself calls for deference, honour and a response of right living.

seeing God
children.comment: Perceiving God in all his fulness. Scripture stresses that God, as spirit, is invisible to sinful human beings. He has, however, been revealed in Jesus Christ, who is his perfect likeness, and he will be seen in all his glory at the end of history when he comes in judgment.

cschildren.title: No human can see the face of God in all his fulness
Privileged individuals may catch a glimpse of God
Threat of death on seeing the face of God
Seeing God in a vision
God may be seen in Jesus Christ
The hope of seeing God at the resurrection

children.title: self-denial
children.comment: The willingness to deny oneself possessions or status, in order to grow in holiness and commitment to God. This practice is commended and illustrated by Jesus Christ himself, and underlies Christian fellowship within the church.

cschildren.title: The wisdom of self-denial
Examples of self-denial in order to put God first
Self-denial is a requirement of following Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: the cost of being a disciple
Peter left everything to follow Jesus Christ
the rewards of self-denial for the sake of the gospel
the example of the Macedonian churches

cschildren.title: Self-denial for the sake of others

primaryrefs.comment: Esther put her own life at risk for the sake of her people

cschildren.title: Self-denial and the example of Jesus Christ

children.title: self-discipline
children.comment: The dedicated training, through the study of Scripture, prayer and self-control, which enables Christians to be more effective witnesses to the gospel, to lead lives more pleasing to God, and to win the crown that awaits those who are victorious over sin.

cschildren.title: Self-discipline is training oneself to be godly
Self-discipline and the study of Scripture
Self-discipline involves learning through experience
Self-discipline should transform the whole person

children.title: A Christian's thoughts should be disciplined
A Christian's speech should be disciplined
A Christian's behaviour should be disciplined
A Christian's body should be disciplined

cschildren.title: Self-discipline prevents God's discipline
Physical self-discipline is of some value, but only in this life
An elder should be self-disciplined
Examples of those who exercised self-discipline
Self-discipline strengthens believers when faced with temptation
The reward for self-discipline is a crown and a prize

children.title: self-examination
children.comment: Reflection on one's own character, motives and actions, in order to judge whether they are truly in accordance with Christian values.

children.title: self-examination, teaching on
children.comment: Self-examination should take place on the basis of God's revelation of himself and the example he sets believers in Jesus Christ. It is especially important before confessing one's sins.

children.title: A lack of self-examination leads to pride and self-delusion
Self-examination is not easy because of humanity's fallen nature
God helps believers in their self-examination
The purpose of self-examination is to lead people to God and amendment of life
Self-examination is especially important when ministering to others
self-examination, examples of
children.comment: Scripture provides numerous examples of self-examination, and its results. In particular, self-examination is often portrayed as leading to repentance.

children.title: Self-examination in the experience of Israel
Self-examination at the entry into the promised land
Self-examination during the war with the Philistines
Self-examination at the time of the exile
Self-examination after returning from exile in Babylon
Self-examination in the experience of individuals
self-examination, teaching on
children.comment: Self-examination should take place on the basis of God's revelation of himself and the example he sets believers in Jesus Christ. It is especially important before confessing one's sins.

children.title: A lack of self-examination leads to pride and self-delusion
Self-examination is not easy because of humanity's fallen nature
God helps believers in their self-examination
The purpose of self-examination is to lead people to God and amendment of life
Self-examination is especially important when ministering to others
self-examination, examples of
children.comment: Scripture provides numerous examples of self-examination, and its results. In particular, self-examination is often portrayed as leading to repentance.

children.title: Self-examination in the experience of Israel
Self-examination at the entry into the promised land
Self-examination during the war with the Philistines
Self-examination at the time of the exile

Self-examination in the experience of individuals
self-sacrifice
children.comment: The willingness to leave one's possessions or to give them to others; to deny oneself to the point of death or to give oneself in the service of God or other people.

cschildren.title: Self-sacrifice as forfeiting one's present comfort for the sake of others
Self-sacrifice as giving one's possessions to others

children.title: Jesus Christ commends the willingness to give away one's possessions
God rewards those who give their possessions away
Sacrificing one's possessions as demonstrated in the life of the church

cschildren.title: Self-sacrifice as leaving all and following Jesus Christ

children.title: Such sacrifice is a condition of discipleship

seealsos.comment: This means loving Jesus Christ over and above one's immediate family.

children.title: Those willing to leave everything to follow Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Self-sacrifice as the metaphorical laying down of one's life for others

children.title: Followers of Jesus Christ are required to give themselves in the service of others
Examples of those who demonstrated such self-sacrifice

cschildren.title: Self-sacrifice as the literal laying down of one's life

children.title: Jesus Christ warns his disciples to be prepared to give their lives
Sacrificing one's life is of no value without love
Examples of those willing to give their lives for the sake of God and others
Examples of those who gave their lives in God's service
spiritual warfare
children.comment: The struggle against the forces of evil, which is a constant feature of the life of faith. Scripture locates the origins of spiritual warfare in the rebellion of Satan and his angels against God and affirms the hope of God's final victory over such forces through Jesus Christ's death and resurrection.

children.title: spiritual warfare, causes of
children.comment: Spiritual warfare has its origin in a rebellion of many angels against God. Satan is seen as the prince of this world, leading an array of forces opposed to God. Although disarmed by Jesus Christ on the cross, they remain a powerful threat to the church and to individual believers.

seealsos.comment: Some believe the kings of Babylon and Tyre to be types of Satan

children.title: Satan and his angels comprise a well-organised army
Satan and his angels will ultimately be fully disarmed by Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: The woman is here thought to be symbolic of the church.

seealsos.comment: The dragon is here thought to be symbolic of the world's persecution (empowered by Satan) of the church.

children.title: Examples of opposition to the first Christians
spiritual warfare, enemies in
children.comment: Christians are at war with the world, the flesh and the devil. Satan empowers the world to attack believers externally, persecuting, deceiving and seducing them. Internally, sinfulness frustrates the efforts of believers to serve God fully.

primaryrefs.comment: ``world'' here refers to the sinful human race, hostile to the truth and to the people of God.

seealsos.comment: The beast may represent the world's antichristian persecution.

children.title: The world has its own false teaching and religion

seealsos.comment: This beast is thought to represent antichristian religion.

children.title: The world seeks to seduce Christians

seealsos.comment: Babylon may represent the world's seduction.

children.title: Sinful human nature is an enemy
He constantly seeks to accuse believers
spiritual warfare, as conflict
children.comment: The warfare believers must fight is spiritual, personal, intense and continual. It calls for courage, determination and prayer, and therefore believers must stand in God's strength and use the armour he has provided.

children.title: spiritual warfare, armour
children.comment: The armour of God refers to the resources that Christians possess for defending themselves against the attacks of the world, the flesh and the devil.

children.title: God is the believer's strength and shield
Believers should be rightly clothed for battle
Believers should put on the full armour of God
The armour of God is worn with prayer
spiritual warfare, causes of
children.comment: Spiritual warfare has its origin in a rebellion of many angels against God. Satan is seen as the prince of this world, leading an array of forces opposed to God. Although disarmed by Jesus Christ on the cross, they remain a powerful threat to the church and to individual believers.

seealsos.comment: Some believe the kings of Babylon and Tyre to be types of Satan

children.title: Satan and his angels comprise a well-organised army
Satan and his angels will ultimately be fully disarmed by Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: The dragon is here thought to be symbolic of the world's persecution (empowered by Satan) of the church.

children.title: God is the believer's strength and shield
Believers should be rightly clothed for battle
Believers should put on the full armour of God
The armour of God is worn with prayer
tithing
children.comment: The practice of offering to God a tenth of the harvest of the land and of livestock, as holy to the LORD. The idea is also used in a more general sense, meaning offering one-tenth of one's income to the Lord.

cschildren.title: Tithing was practised before the giving of the OT law

primaryrefs.comment: Abraham offered a tenth of the goods taken in battle, apparently in thankfulness to God for victory.

cschildren.title: Tithing under the law

children.title: Tithing extends to all kinds of produce and livestock

primaryrefs.comment: Cereal and fruit offerings could be commuted to money.

children.title: All tithes were paid to the Levites
Tithes were to be paid in a designated place

secondaryrefs.comment: Tithes were paid in Jerusalem, or every three years in towns where the tithe feast was eaten.

children.title: Levites offered a tenth to the LORD

cschildren.title: Uses of the tithe

children.title: A three-yearly gift to the poor

cschildren.title: Tithing of minor items must not lead to neglect of major matters
Freewill offerings were made in addition to the tithe

children.title: They were given according to ability

seealsos.comment: There is no specific command in the NT for the church to tithe, but many commands to give generously and to support the Lord's work.

cschildren.title: Blessing promised to those who tithe
Failure to tithe and abuses of the tithe

children.title: In the preaching of John the Baptist
In the preaching of Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: The urgency of the need to proclaim the gospel

seealsos.comment: in the light of the coming day of the Lord

cschildren.title: Examples of urgent summons by officials

children.title: watchfulness
children.comment: The state of being alert and expectant; watching over someone in one's care or waiting for the arrival of someone important or for some significant event. Scripture lays particular emphasis on the need to watch for the second coming of Jesus Christ.

children.title: watchfulness, divine
children.comment: The Lord's alertness to the needs of his people, his constant care for them and his awareness of the power and evil intent of their enemies.

children.title: The Lord's watchfulness over his people in danger or trouble
The Lord's watchfulness means that his people's needs are met
The Lord's watchfulness means that he hears his people's prayers
The Lord's watchfulness with a view to correction
The Lord's watchfulness in seeking out those who have gone astray
People are vulnerable without the Lord's watchfulness
watchfulness, of leaders
children.comment: Leaders must be alert to the needs of those they serve and also to the dangers that surround believers in the world. The OT teaching on watchmen provides an indication of the importance of watchfulness and the responsibility of those called to be watchful.

children.title: Leaders are required to be watchful
They must warn against false teachers

primaryrefs.comment: Elders are called overseers in Acts 20:28; 1Ti 3:2; Tit 1:7; 1Pe 5:2.

children.title: Examples of leaders' warnings to churches
Leaders need to watch over their own lives
Watchmen sometimes fail to be watchful
watchfulness, of believers
children.comment: Alertness to dangers and blessings in the Christian life, and also to opportunities to do good.

children.title: The danger of neglecting the word of God
The danger of damage to the Lord's work
Watchfulness for the return of Jesus Christ
Watchfulness for opportunities to serve the Lord
Contrast with the watchfulness of unbelievers with evil intent
watchfulness, divine
children.comment: The Lord's alertness to the needs of his people, his constant care for them and his awareness of the power and evil intent of their enemies.

witnessing
children.comment: The task of declaring what has happened, especially in relation to the life, death and resurrection of Jesus Christ. Believers are given the responsibility of proclaiming the good news of Jesus Christ to the world at all times and in all places.

children.title: witnessing, importance of
children.comment: Sharing the good news about God and Jesus Christ with others is a work to which some believers have a special calling, but in which all believers are to take part.

children.title: Witnessing is sharing the truth of God

primaryrefs.comment: Paul, in prison for his faith, encourages the young leader, Timothy.

children.title: Witnessing is a task for all God's people
Witnessing is a major aspect of Christian living
Examples of witnessing to Jesus Christ
Witnessing to the resurrection of Jesus Christ
witnessing, approaches to
children.comment: Scripture provides teaching, supported by examples, concerning when believers should witness, the methods they are to use, and the manner of doing it.

seealsos.comment: Paul uses the account of his conversion in witnessing.

children.title: witnessing, and Holy Spirit
children.comment: Christian witnessing is made effective through the empowering, strengthening and guiding of the Holy Spirit. Witnessing is an aspect of spiritual warfare, and believers need supernatural aid to face Satan's opposition.

children.title: The Holy Spirit supports believers in witnessing
The Holy Spirit empowers effective witness
He confirms the testimony of believers
He convinces people of their need
He brings people to new birth
The Holy Spirit guides believers in witnessing

seealsos.comment: Stephen's witnessing leads him to become the first Christian martyr. The English word ``martyr'' comes from the Greek word for ``witness''

children.comment: Sharing the good news about God and Jesus Christ with others is a work to which some believers have a special calling, but in which all believers are to take part.

primaryrefs.comment: Paul, in prison for his faith, encourages the young leader, Timothy.

Witnessing is a major aspect of Christian living

seealsos.comment: Paul uses the account of his conversion in witnessing.

The Holy Spirit empowers effective witness
He confirms the testimony of believers
